bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, February 5, 1917

div1.p: Carter writes to Blue regarding his appearance as a witness in a South Carolina lawsuit.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, February 5, 1917
div1.opener:
LC
Copy
S. Carolina
February 5, 1917.
Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
Referring to Bureau Letter of January 29/17 (
relative to my appearing as a witness in a suit in which the
Colleton Cypress Co. is involved, I would respectfully sub-
mit that the ruling given in quotation marks in this letter--
viz. “It would not appear advisable that officers of the Ser-
vice should be authorized or required to take steps to qual-
ify as witnesses in particular cases”--does not specifically
apply in this case. I do not think that there is any ques-
tion of my making any examinations or surveys so as to qual-
ify myself as a witness in this suit. The season of the year
forbids. I have already visited the general locality (Febru-
ary 1916) and advised what examinations should be made. I
presume I am simply wanted to testify to such things as I am
already qualified to do. It is not a case of qualifying as
a witness, but of testifying. Frankly, I doubt if my testi-
mony would be specially important, except as an expert in the
epidemiology of malaria.

No personal gain would accrue to me from testifying in
this case, see my letter of Jan. 10, 1917, and my sole reas-
on for wishing to comply with Mr. Bell's request is that I
feel it an obligation to him to do so if it be practicable,
on account of having visited the locality with him and ad-
vised with him about it--the understanding then being that
I would be willing to appear in court if practicable and it
was judged desireable. It is in no sense an advantage to me
to go as I need the time for other things.

There is one somewhat annoyingg complication, however:
The Surgeon General told me on January 18th., voluntarily,
as I had not spoken on the matter, that someone had spoken
to him about the Colleton case and that I could get leave
of absence at the proper time and I had informed Mr. Bell
of this before the receipt of Bureau Letter of Jan. 29/17.
I will, however, now forward him a copy of your letter of
Jan. 29th. for his information.
